sections.Confirmation:
This course syllabus was confirmed by The IT Faculty Board on 2006-11-17 to be valid
from 2007-09-01.
sections.Position in the educational system:
The course is a part of the Computer Science Master's programme and a single subject
course at the University of Gothenburg.
The course is labeled as an AXX course.
The course can be part of the following programmes: 1) Computer Science, Master's
Programme (N2COS), 2) Computer Science, Bachelor's Programme (N1COS) and 3)
No translation available (NDATM)
sections.Entry requirements:
To be eligible for the course students should have successfully completed a first year of
studies within the subject Computer Science or equivalent. Spefically, a course in
Human-Compter-Interaction is required.
sections.Learning outcomes:
The course focuses on data collection and analysis methods to use within interaction
design. After completing this course the student is expected to be able to:
• Understand what aspect affects the information gathered in methods for interaction
analysis
• Identify user requirements through user studies
• Evaluate design solutions regarding user requirements
• Plan and execute interaction analysis studies.
sections.Course content:
The course consists of lectures, seminars and exercises based on a couple of central
themes. Each theme is presented in a lecture and students are then given practical
experience through assignments or exercises. The theme is then concluded by a
discussion to reflect upon the practical experiences. The themes studied include:
• Core concepts and main theoretical frameworks
• Methods to identify user requirements
• Selection criteria for studies and what consequences these have
• Consequences of the context of studies
• Mediation artifacts
• Theoretical and empirical perspectives
sections.Assessment: The course is graded by group exercises and individual exams.
sections.Grades: The grading scale comprises: Fail, Pass, Pass with distinction.
sections.Course evaluation:
The course is evaluated through meetings both during and after the course between
teachers and student representatives. Further, an anonymous questionnaire can be used
to ensure written information. The outcome of the evaluations serves to improve the
course by indicating which parts could be added, improved, changed or removed.
